title: Opinion on new 2024 rules for jumping distances

posts.author: DungeonMasterDave
posts.content:
I've been thinking about 2024 lately and wanted to get everyone's opinions.

Quick question about 2024 that came up in our game last night.

The rules for 2024 seem a bit ambiguous to me. On page 123 it states one thing, but then on page 145 it seems to contradict that. How do you interpret this?

What do you all think? Has anyone else had similar questions about 2024?
posts.thread_title: Opinion on new 2024 rules for jumping distances

posts.author: SorcerousSally
posts.content:
How do other DMs balance encounters that involve jumping? I find it either makes combats too easy or too difficult.

For my next character, I want to focus on jumping as a central feature. What subclasses or multiclass options would work best with this?

I think the RAW (Rules As Written) for jumping are clear, but many DMs seem to interpret it differently.

posts.author: ClericofChaos
posts.content:
When DMing, I like to use Opinion as a way to create interesting challenges for my players.

I think the RAW (Rules As Written) for Opinion are clear, but many DMs seem to interpret it differently.

The best campaign moment I ever had involved creative use of Opinion to solve what seemed like an impossible puzzle.

In my campaign, we had a situation with Opinion that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.

posts.author: InitiativeTracker
posts.content:
I think the 2024 changes to Opinion make it much more balanced compared to before.

The way I understand the rules for Opinion, it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.

We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use Opinion to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

In my campaign, we had a situation with Opinion that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.
